data.title: Jack Dempsey, the golden years
data.meta_description: Danny Summers Editors note: This is Part Three of a three-part series on the life of boxing legend Jack Dempsey. Dempsey’s career began in Gold …
data.text:
Danny Summers

Editors note: This is Part Three of a three-part series on the

life of boxing legend Jack Dempsey. Dempsey’s career began in Gold

Camp, where he learned the basics of fighting. He estimated he had

hundreds of fights in Victor and Cripple Creek between the years of

1911 and 1916.

From his humble beginnings in Manassa, to his wild days in Gold

Camp, to his rise to Heavyweight Champion of the World, Jack

Dempsey still is one of the most revered American athletes

ever.

Dempsey lived until 1983 when he died at the age of 87 — nearly

60 years after his last professional fight. And while he was one of

the most famous people in the world during the Roaring 20s, he

continued to have enormous popularity throughout his life, drawing

tens of thousands to events.

Once Dempsey became Heavyweight champion in 1919, he slowed down

the frequency of his fights. He fought just nine times until his

retirement in 1927, when he lost a rematch to Gene Tunney, whom he

had relinquished his title to after a seven-year reign. Dempsey’s

professional record included 66 wins (51 knockouts), 6 losses and

11 draws. Dempsey is listed No. 7 on Ring Magazine’s 100 Greatest

Boxers of All-Time.

Dempsey continued to fight exhibition matches until 1940, and in

1935, he opened Jack Dempsey’s Broadway Restaurant in New York

City’s Times Square, which he kept open until 1974.

Dempsey’s friends ran the circuit from Harry Houdini to Judge

John Sirica, who presided over the Watergate trials.

Dempsey was married four times — two of which were notable

Hollywood actresses (Estelle Taylor and Hannah Williams). He was

married to his last wife, Deanna Piatelli, from 1943 until his

death. He often said she should have been his first. He considered

this last marriage a happy one, and he adopted Deanna’s daughter,

Barbara.

By all accounts, Dempsey was content with his post-fight career

and enjoyed retirement. It was a far cry from his days in Gold

Camp, where he worked long hours in the mines, partied hard in the

bars and trained even harder to become champion by the age of

24.

One negative thing that haunted Dempsey for years was his

deferment-based claim during World War I. He registered for the

draft, but said he was the sole support for his family (he was

married to his first wife Maxine Cates at the time). In 1920 he was

labeled a “slacker” by the government and brought to trial as a

draft dodger. Maxine was the government’s key witness. He was

eventually cleared of all charges.

Dempsey got his chance to refute any remaining criticism when

the United States entered World War II. He joined the New York

State National Guard and was given a commission as a first

lieutenant. He resigned that commission to accept a commission as a

lieutenant in the Coast Guard Reserve, and reported for active duty

in June 1942 at the Coast Guard Training Station in New York. He

was assigned director of physical education.

Dempsey was promoted to lieutenant commander in December of 1942

and commander in March, 1944. In 1945 he was on the attack

transport USS Arthur Middleton for the invasion of Okinawa, Japan.

In 1952 he was given an honorable discharge from the Coast Guard

Reserve.

In a 1950 poll, the Associated Press selected Dempsey as the

greatest fighter of the first half of the century.

Manassa paid tribute to its favorite son in 1966 when it opened

a museum in Dempsey’s honor. It is housed in the cabin in which

Dempsey was born. It contains several artifacts of Dempsey’s

career, including gloves, and numerous black-and-white photographs,

which line the walls.

Dempsey is buried in the Southampton Cemetery in Southampton,

New York. The street where Madison Square Garden is located is

called Jack Dempsey Corner.

Dempsey was a universally accepted sports star. With his bobbing

and weaving stance, amazing speed, graceful agility, and pure

power, he will forever remain the perfect boxer, and one of the

greatest box office attractions of all time.

One can visit the Cripple Creek District Museum to see more on

the early legend of Jack Dempsey.
